0.title: Simplr Router
0.headline: Simplr Router
0.body:
A small and effective routing solution for Web Components 


  
    Follow Guides 
  
    Browse Docs

1.title: Simplr Router
1.headline: Why Simplr RouterQuick and simple
1.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

2.title: Simplr Router
2.headline: Small
2.body: No dependencies and a small codebase means less breaking parts. 0 dependencies means that what you see is what you get.

3.title: Simplr Router
3.headline: Easy to transition into
3.body: Works by utilizing the native API's used for navigation and therefore doesn't require any extra steps compared to your every day MPA.

4.title: Simplr Router
4.headline: Web Component focused
4.body: Built with web components, for web components. Simplr Router was designed from the get go to be used in web component applications.

5.title: Simplr Router
5.headline: Customizable
5.body: Even though there's no configuration necessary to get started, the router ships with a lot of customizability to fit your needs.

6.title: Simplr Router
6.headline: Performant
6.body: Allowing for lazy loading and creating dynamic routes, Simplr Router is a great library for projects of all sizes.

7.title: Docs
7.headline: Docs
7.body:
The API documentation has references to most of the public facing API's
the Simplr Router exposes. 

  
    
        
         
       

  Show Navigation

8.title: Guides
8.headline: Guides
8.body:
This section of the documentation provides some examples, recipes and references for using Simplr Router. 
If you are new to Web Components, you should start from Using a Starter  
If you are more experiences, you could look into the Your first Setup  -section and read through the recipes. 

  
    
        
         
       

  Show Navigation

11.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
11.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
11.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.

12.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
12.headline: Using an outlet
12.body:
render ( )  { } 
  return  html` < main >  
    < div  class = " logo"  >  < img  alt = " open-wc logo"   src = ${ logo}    />  </ div >  
    < simplr-router-outlet >  </ simplr-router-outlet >  
  </ main >  
   `  ; 
} 
  
After the outlet has been added, Simplr Router will look for a outlet when navigating. If one is found, it is used instead
of the default behavior. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

13.title: Getting started: Your first setup

14.title: Recipes: Child routes
14.headline: Recipes: Child routes

15.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
15.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
15.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

27.title: Getting started: Using a starter
27.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
27.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

28.title: Getting started: Using a starter
28.headline: Initial setup
28.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

29.title: Getting started: Using a starter
29.headline: Installing the router
29.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

36.headline: Guides
36.body:
This section of the documentation provides some examples, recipes and references for using Simplr Router. 
If you are new to Web Components, you should start from Using a Starter  
If you are more experiences, you could look into the Your first Setup  -section and read through the recipes.

37.title: API: Helper function
37.headline: API: Helper function
37.body:
Helper functions are callable functions that plug into the currently active Simplr Router instance
without the developer having to hold onto a reference of the router. 
Helper functions are exported from the same package as the router itself. 
import  {  getBreadcrumbs }  from  "@simplr-wc/router" ; 
  




















Name Type Description   getBreadcrumbs() Function(): SimplrRouterBreadcrumb[] Returns the breadcrumbs for the current route.  getCurrentView() Function(): SimplrRouterNavigationData Returns the current view.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

39.title: API: Route
39.headline: API: Route
39.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

}

a.title: API: Router Options
a.headline: API: Router Options
a.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

c.title: API: Route
c.headline: API: Route
c.body:
Type name: SimplrRoute 























































Name Type Description   path string The URL path for the route  component string The view component name for the route  name string Name of the view route  import Function An import function for lazy loading. e.g. () => import("./my-view.js")  guard Function A guard function to check view access  routes SimplrRoute[] An array of subroutes that inherit paths from the parent route  slots [x: string]: string | Function An array of slots to append to the view component  pattern [x: string]: string | RegExp pattern to match dynamic route keys  redirect string | { name: string } Path to redirect to

e.title: API: Router
e.headline: API: Router
e.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 



































Name Type Description   init() Function() Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function(ChangeViewObject) Change view to given path or named route.  use(middlewareClass) Function(any) Add middleware to Simplr Router.  getBreadcrumbs() Function(): SimplrRouterBreadcrumb[] Returns the breadcrumbs for the current route.  getCurrentView() Function(): SimplrRouterNavigationData Returns the current view.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

f.title: Customizing: Changing routing root
f.headline: Customizing: Changing routing root

g.title: Customizing: Middleware
g.headline: Customizing: Middleware
g.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

h.title: Customizing: Middleware
h.headline: Reactive events
h.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

i.title: Customizing: Middleware
i.headline: Overriding events
i.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

j.title: Customizing: Middleware
j.headline: Using a middleware

and bundle it correctly, even if the file gets renamed.

2m.title: Recipes: Dynamic routes
2m.headline: Recipes: Dynamic routes
2m.body:
When creating frontend routing, often you might want to map a route by a given pattern. To achieve this,
dynamic routing is needed. 
Example of a case where dynamic routing could be used is when creating a user view with a dynamic ID to differentiate between multiple users. 
const  routes =  [ 
    {  path:  "" ,  component:  "front-page"  } , 
    {  path:  "user" ,  component:  "user-list"  } , 
    {  path:  "user/:id" ,  component:  "user-profile"  } , 
] ; 
  
When navigating to /user/123 , the id  property of the view will be provided the paramter from the URL, in this case 123 .

2z.title: Simplr Router
2z.headline: Why Simplr RouterQuick and simple
2z.body: Simple to get up and running. Basic setup in just a few lines of code.

3a.title: API: Router Options
3a.headline: API: Router Options
3a.body:
Type name: SimplrRouterOptions 








































Name Type Description   routes SimplrRoute Routes provided for the Simplr Router.  rootPath string Root path of the router. If the root is not the origin of the host.  transitionSpeed number Transition speed of view transitions in milliseconds.  notFoundAction Function Action triggered when a view is not found.  forbiddenAction Function Action triggered when access to a view is forbidden by a guard function.  debugging boolean Enable debugging.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

3b.title: API: Router
3b.headline: API: Router
3b.body:
Type name: SimplrRouter 



































Name Type Description   init() Function() Initialize Simplr Router and start navigating.  changeView() Function(ChangeViewObject) Change view to given path or named route.  use(middlewareClass) Function(any) Add middleware to Simplr Router.  getBreadcrumbs() Function(): SimplrRouterBreadcrumb[] Returns the breadcrumbs for the current route.  getCurrentView() Function(): SimplrRouterNavigationData Returns the current view.    

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

3d.title: Customizing: Middleware
3d.headline: Customizing: Middleware
3d.body:
Simplr Router supports middleware to enhance the base functionality of the Router. 
A middleware can be easily plugged into the router and used across the project. 
A middleware instance can implement one or all of the middleware functions exposed by the router. The functions are as follows:

3e.title: Customizing: Middleware
3e.headline: Reactive events
3e.body:
These functions are used to react to events administrated by Simplr Router. 

























Method Type Description   routerNavigating Consumes: viewObject  Produces: viewObject   routerNavigating is called after the router has resolved the route it needs to navigate to. The viewObject will contain data about the route, if one was found.  This function can be used to apply additional checks to the routes, or for manipulating the route data before navigation actually happens.  Another use-case could be for example logging or analytics      routerNavigationComplete Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   routerNavigationComplete is called after the navigation has finished.  This middleware hook could be used to apply additional effects to views after navigation has fully completed.    newViewAddedToDOM Consumes: container  Produces: Nothing   newViewAddedToDOM is called as soon as the new view element has hit the DOM, and is accessible by javascript. This middleware hook could be used to apply some additional effects as soon as possible, even before the whole transition animation has finished.

3f.title: Customizing: Middleware
3f.headline: Overriding events
3f.body:
These functions are used to override the default behavior of Simplr Router 




















Method Type Description   addViewToContainerOverride Consumes: container, viewObject  Produces: Nothing   addViewToContainerOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for appending a new View component into the Simplr Router Container.  If this function is defined in a middleware, it overrides the default functionality with the new one.  A use case for overriding the existing implementation could be for example support for a different javascript framework. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation         createComponentOverride Consumes: view Produces: component   createComponentOverride overwrites the functionality Simplr Router has for creating the View Component before appending it into the Simplr Router Container.  Some frameworks might have a different way of creating a fresh component from the default implementation of Simplr Router. In these cases it's worth consideration to overwrite this function to impelment a custom builder for the view component.  The default functionality uses the document.createElement()-function to create the view, so if a different method is needed, this function can do that. An example on this can be found from the official React Middleware implementation

3o.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3o.headline: Getting started: Using a starter
3o.body:
Simplr Router was built to work with Web Component environments and therefore the Open-WC starter 
is a perfect base for using this router.

3p.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3p.headline: Initial setup
3p.body:
Start by initializing your project with the Open-WC starter 
npm  init @open-wc
  
This will prompt you to generate a starter application for your web component project. You should choose to create
an application, and add whatever optional tooling you need. 
The setup we're using in this tutorial is as follows: 
✔ What would you like to do today? › Scaffold a new project
✔ What would you like to scaffold? › Application
✔ What would you like to add? ›
✔ Would you like to use typescript? › No
✔ What is the tag name of your application/web component? … simplr-router-demo

3q.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3q.headline: Installing the router
3q.body:
npm  install  @simplr-wc/router
  
This command will install the Simplr Router to your project and will be ready to use as soon as it's finished installing.

3r.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3r.headline: Configuring History API fallback

3u.headline: Adding views
3u.body:
Next we will want to do some actual routing. This requires a few steps: 

Create a view to navigate to 
Add it as a route 
Create a link to navigate to the page

3y.title: Getting started: Using a starter
3y.headline: Next steps
3y.body:
You're now all set to start building your application on top of Simplr Router. For more configuration
options and recipes, check out the recipes  section. For a thorough look into the actual API
behing Simplr Router, check out the docs . 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

3z.title: Getting started: Using an outlet
3z.headline: Getting started: Using an outlet
3z.body:
Simplr Router creates a container for your views that fills the whole screen by default. 
In some cases you might want to only have a part of the page change instead of the whole content. 
In these cases an outlet can be used to determine the area in which content changes. 
Determining an outlet is done by creating a simplr-router-outlet  somewhere on your web page.
